fields.description: After creating about 8 tags for 2 instances, it was detected that the UI's proxy was spilling error messages out when trying to call "DescribeTags" to the CLC. When directly interacted with the CLC using euca2ools, the command was returning: # euca-describe-tags DescribeTagsType: Failed to find tags for [Tag value=null resourceIdFunction=constant(null) resourceType=null ownerUserId=null ownerUserName=null ownerAccountNumber=431447864420 ownerAccountName=null uniqueName=null ownerFullNameCached=null state=null lastState=null stateChangeStack=null displayName=null id=null version=null creationTimestamp=null lastUpdateTimestamp=null naturalId=null] When examining the error messages of the UI's proxy, there are more detailed information included: 2013-03-19 17:33:03 WARNING 406 POST /ec2?Action=DescribeTags (192.168.7.1) 69.53ms 2013-03-19 17:33:03 ERROR EC2ResponseError: 406 Not Acceptable DescribeTagsTypeFailed to find tags for [Tag value=null resourceIdFunction=constant(null) resourceType=null ownerUserId=null ownerUserName=null ownerAccountNumber=505861017013 ownerAccountName=null uniqueName=null ownerFullNameCached=null state=null lastState=null stateChangeStack=null displayName=null id=null version=null creationTimestamp=null lastUpdateTimestamp=null naturalId=null]com.eucalyptus.cloud.util.NoSuchMetadataException: Failed to find tags for [Tag value=null resourceIdFunction=constant(null) resourceType=null ownerUserId=null ownerUserName=null ownerAccountNumber=505861017013 ownerAccountName=null uniqueName=null ownerFullNameCached=null state=null lastState=null stateChangeStack=null displayName=null id=null version=null creationTimestamp=null lastUpdateTimestamp=null naturalId=null] Caused by: org.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: could not execute query Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: Couldn't perform the operation prepareStatement: You can't perform any operations on this connection. It has been automatically closed by Proxool for some reason (see logs). com.eucalyptus.cloud.util.NoSuchMetadataException: Failed to find tags for [Tag value=null resourceIdFunction=constant(null) resourceType=null ownerUserId=null ownerUserName=null ownerAccountNumber=505861017013 ownerAccountName=null uniqueName=null ownerFullNameCached=null state=null lastState=null stateChangeStack=null displayName=null id=null version=null creationTimestamp=null lastUpdateTimestamp=null naturalId=null] at com.eucalyptus.tags.Tags.list(Tags.java:95) at com.eucalyptus.tags.Tags.list(Tags.java:75) at com.eucalyptus.tags.TagManager.describeTags(TagManager.java:200) at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor458.invoke(Unknown Source) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:616) at org.mule.model.resolvers.AbstractEntryPointResolver.invokeMethod(AbstractEntryPointResolver.java:147) at org.mule.model.resolvers.ReflectionEntryPointResolver.invoke(ReflectionEntryPointResolver.java:127) at org.mule.model.resolvers.DefaultEntryPointResolverSet.invoke(DefaultEntryPointResolverSet.java:50) at org.mule.component.DefaultLifecycleAdapter.intercept(DefaultLifecycleAdapter.java:202) at org.mule.component.AbstractJavaComponent.invokeComponentInstance(AbstractJavaComponent.java:82) at org.mule.component.AbstractJavaComponent.doOnCall(AbstractJavaComponent.java:73) at org.mule.component.AbstractComponent.onCall(AbstractComponent.java:87) at org.mule.mo ...
fields.summary: euca-describe-tags command fails after creating a few tags

comments.body:
It wasn't only the describe-tags command that was failing:

[root@eucahost-51-73 ~]# euca-describe-instances 
DescribeInstancesType: org.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: Cannot open connection
[root@eucahost-51-73 ~]# euca-describe-volumes 
DescribeVolumesType: org.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: Cannot open connection


Also, it should be worth noting that when the UI is running, it makes periodic API calls to the CLC, which in turn, ends up crashing with the errors above.

Stack trace from the call "euca-describe-tags --debug":


com.eucalyptus.cloud.util.NoSuchMetadataException: Failed to find tags for [Tag value=null resourceIdFunction=constant(null) resourceType=null ownerUserId=null ownerUserName=null ownerAccountNumber=431447864420 ownerAccountName=null uniqueName=null ownerFullNameCached=null state=null lastState=null stateChangeStack=null displayName=null id=null version=null creationTimestamp=null lastUpdateTimestamp=null naturalId=null]

[~kyolee] you are blocked from making progress on UI until this is fixed?
Looks like tag deletion could be leaking connections on failure (or there could be a leak unrelated to tagging)

I'm not fully blocked on it, but I have to constantly create and delete the tags so that the system doesn't fall into the status where it crashes the UI.

It appears that the system is able to handle a small number of resource tags, however, the system will fall into the faulty state above when about 7 to 9 tags are created.

[~awithrow][~tjcramer]: [~kyolee]just told me in IRC that he cannot get to feature complete on resource tagging until this is fixed. 

jmolo
kyolee_: do you need 5456 fixed to get to feature complete?
4:32
kyolee_
4:32
jmolo: yes

What can we do to make sure this issue is addressed ASAP, please?
[~kyolee], are you able to reproduce this problem by creating two tags for two instances? If not, does this unblock console development until full investigation in sprint 6?

Currently the workaround for this issue is to create and quickly remove the tags before the system falls into the failed state.

However, the development of the resource tag widget has been reached to the point that it becomes necessary to have more than 2 tags to ensure the complete coverage of the widget's functionality.

So, in that sense, I'm blocked since I won't be able to create the realistic user environment to fully test the resource tag widget.

Please feel free to ask any questions.

Thank you!

Kyo

This is from an e-mail between several involved parties on March 22nd.

Pretty interesting. Let me talk about the proxy behavior and recent changes that may shed some light on this. in 3.2 and up till recently, the proxy would only request information for resources (describe calls) at 20 second intervals for most resources. This was due to the caching layer and the default pollfreq setting of 20 seconds. For images, we set this to 60 seconds. For other calls, like RunInstances, AssociateAddress, etc, those calls weren't throttled by the proxy and would cause the cache to be invalidated, so some code in the bowser "could" modify a resource, then request a list of that resource and effectively hit the CLC with both calls fairly quickly.

A few weeks back, I made a change to help support filter'ed requests such that if a filter was set by the user, the filter parameters would be passed with the describe call and be used in the caching layer to indicate the contents of the describe. So, if 1 request were made with one set of filters (or none), the request might hit the CLC (if the cache were stale). If another request is made with different filter parameters, it would force the current cached result to be ignored and another request would be made to the CLC. This is necessary to leverage the filtering features of the API the CLC supports. If 2 requests are made for the same resource with the same filter parameters, the cache may be able to service the second request if it arrives within the appropriate time window.

OK. Having said all that, I'm trying to figure out how exactly the same describe request could get through the proxy in the small time window to trigger replay detection. Can we determine the exact request string that is causing this problem? I should be able to simulate with the proxy client in python. I can write a test case to try to reproduce this.

[~dkavanagh], why do we think this is related to replay detection?

I have tried to reproduce this issue but have been unsuccessful. If we know how to reproduce the issue (preferably by using the API/CLI) then please add that information to the bug.

I'll write more later, but I wanted to capture and error I'm seeing when the proxy sends a lot of requests to the CLC. It is an indication that the CLC isn't degrading gracefully under load. Further, it shows it blames the problem on the client by giving a 406 response. AWS will typically return a 503 if the service is loaded and the user needs to retry. 4xx errors should be reserved for client errors, not a failure of the server due to load. EC2ResponseError: EC2ResponseError: 406 Not Acceptable DescribeImagesTypecould not execute queryorg.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: could not execute query Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: Couldn't perform the operation prepareStatement: You can't perform any operations on this connection. It has been automatically closed by Proxool for some reason (see logs). org.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: could not execute query at org.hibernate.exception.SQLStateConverter.handledNonSpecificException(SQLStateConverter.java:140) at org.hibernate.exception.SQLStateConverter.convert(SQLStateConverter.java:128) at org.hibernate.exception.JDBCExceptionHelper.convert(JDBCExceptionHelper.java:66) at org.hibernate.loader.Loader.doList(Loader.java:2452) at org.hibernate.loader.Loader.listIgnoreQueryCache(Loader.java:2192) at org.hibernate.loader.Loader.list(Loader.java:2187) at org.hibernate.loader.criteria.CriteriaLoader.list(CriteriaLoader.java:119) at org.hibernate.impl.SessionImpl.list(SessionImpl.java:1706) at org.hibernate.impl.CriteriaImpl.list(CriteriaImpl.java:347) at com.eucalyptus.entities.Entities.query(Entities.java:282) at com.eucalyptus.entities.Transactions$6.get(Transactions.java:272) at com.eucalyptus.entities.Transactions$6.get(Transactions.java:269)

Talking with Kyo, he had been following my advice on a workaround for some proxy caching problem. That workaround was to set the proxy polling frequency to 0, which meant caches would always be stale. That's wasn't a problem until some changes I introduced just after the austin ui summit a few weeks back. The changes meant that a timer was created in the proxy for each resource to pull info from the CLC. The 0 value was now causing a huge amount of requests to the CLC! It is not a valid condition and I will be adding a lower limit to that value which is > 0 for sure.

That probably answers the replay detection question (as far as what caused it). The comment above is now a more pressing concern from my standpoint. Steve hinted at a connection leak, and I can say I've seen this when only describe operations were being issued (at a fairly high rate). I suspect some simple python code to hit the API calls directly could be used to force this condition if it helps in debug.
one more bit of info. I have a CLC that has produced the above 406 error and when I resume a "normal" level of requests to it, I still see failures. Going to restart it now.
